content:
Failure
Found: z x w
Expected: x w z
(validator 5)

I cant find anything in the problem statement that specifies the order has to be the same as in the varList.

My clash had no 100% and a bunch of 80%.

Order of output should be specified. I would assume Validator 5 first line would be "z x w" because it was in that order in declarations. also no open test for that different order doesn't give a chance to fix the issue

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a good one

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is tricky to get fast solution

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I wrote a c# code in around 5 minutes

Your definition of "a bound variable" is confusing, at least to me.

It seems circular.  You are saying "A bound variable is a variable that is bound..." but isn't that like saying "a chartreuse shirt is a shirt that is chartreuse"?
If I don't know what chartreuse means, this definition does not help me.

Yes, of course folks can google, but for a clash, is there enough time?

Output section
* Please format NONE as a constant i.e. {{NONE}}.

Cases
* Tests and validators should be similar but remain different.

Thanks.

Well, I would argue that it's not circular because it says that a bound variable is a variable that is bound "by a λ and occurs in its expression". I guess I could make further clarification that the left-hand side of the dot is the formal parameter and the right-hand side is the expression? 

What do you think?
I just ran into the exact same problem, seems like it's not fixed. Maybe just make the variable output order explicitly alphabetical?

This issue is still not fixed. The ordering of the variables is arbitrary looking at the OP's code. They don't do any sorting, it's a mix of when the variable appears in the expression, but also at which point in the expression it becomes clear which category the variable belongs to... it's not really fair to expect such a complex sort for this. I won my clash with 80%, 2nd place got 80% too, the rest got 0%.

It should just be alphabetical, but the issue is that would require edits to output forTest 3 and Validator 3, and Validator 5 would also need editing. The rest of them would be the same though...

I'm tempted to edit it, but it's a pretty big choice, hopefully JCProgrammer will respond.

It's not alphabetical. It's the order in which they are declared in the expression. For validator 5, the bound variables, in the order they are encountered in the BODY, are x, w, and z, because they are bound by a lambda.
v is of course free.
y and u are neither because they are the formal parameter to a lambda.

Ok, so your rule is essentially:

"For bound or free variables, sort them in the order they appear in the final [[expr]], while for the variables that are neither, sort them by the order they appear in the overall expression."
(Note: what I call 'the final [[expr]]' is what you referred to as the 'BODY', but I've changed it to match the language you've used in the statement)

I think you need to state it clearly, as currently all you say is:
"The variable output order matters!" which is very ambiguous.

The way I sorted it in my clash was all of them sorted by the order they appear in the overall expression, not the 'BODY' for bound and free vars. I got 100% on tests and it seemed like the natural way to sort them based on your note that 'variable output order matters', but then got 80% on validators.

The other commenters and I were only suggesting alphabetical as an alternative because it seemed like it would avoid confusion, but if you can just edit your note to describe this way of sorting that you've used, then that works. :) But you should also add a test case that differentiates between these, like Validator 5 does, or else clashers won't have a means to debug the sort order in-clash.
Sure, I can do that. Sorry for the confusion! I added a test that mirrors Validator 5 and added the statement that you wrote.

I think you are assuming that everyone knows the term.  

In other words:
I don't know what "bound" means is, and your definition uses "bound" to define what "bound" is.

Admittedly I have not taken a ton of math classes, so maybe every other person knows, but that is at least my perspective.  Think about it :)
I can clarify it as such: "A variable x is bound if it exists in BOTH the <var> AND <expr> parts of λ<var><expr>".

Yes, I think that's better.

Personally, I still don't understand, but your puzzle is the first time I ever heard of "simplified lambda calculus" so maybe that's my problem.
But I definitely would need more time than 5 minutes to try to wrap my brain around this.
